awd_titl_txt: Models of Complex Experimentation: Attribute Discovery, Contextual Experimentation, and Experimentation on Causal Graphs
awd_abstract_narration:
This award funds research in economic theory. The goal to analyze learning and strategic experimentation in complex environments where information is important but is also not always easily discovered. Experimentation is key to innovation and progress in technology, public policy, markets, and science. The growing availability of big data and wide spread use of experimental methods mean that businesses and governments conduct trial or experimental efforts to quickly evaluate everything from marketing plans to government outreach efforts. Yet such data abundance and complexity also leaves room for selective and distorted learning.  This research will develop a framework to study such distortions in three complex environments: multi-site evaluation of social programs; small-scale experimentation and policy diffusion in across states in a federal system of government; and dynamic learning of causal relationships.

The research seeks to contribute to existing work in optimal attribute learning, causal experimentation, and strategic experimentation with correlated outcomes. The PI will introduce and analyze optimal experimentation in three distinct environments in which the object of experimentation is complex. The first project studies a principal-agent model of experimentation and persuasion through selective discovery of attributes of a multi-attribute object of common interest. Conceptually, the study draws an analogy between optimal attribute sampling and small-scale multi-site evaluation of social programs. Methodologically, it offers a novel theoretical framework based on Gaussian processes. The second project will employ this Gaussian framework to build a dynamic model of experimentation in federal systems. Experimentation performed by individual states within a federal union is a striking example of the interplay between small-scale context-based experimentation and large-scale policy adoption. The analysis seeks to explain empirical patterns of horizontal and vertical policy diffusion. Motivated by the debate on mechanism experiments as an alternative to traditional policy experiments in empirical work, the third project studies strategic experimentation on a causal graph of random variables. The analysis will seek to identify formal conditions under which mechanism experiments dominate policy experiments, by marrying tools of causal graph theory with classic multi-armed bandit problems.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This award supported work developing a novel methodological framework for analyzing experimentation in contexts in which economic agents choose not only how long to experiment with a novel object (a product, a policy, a technology etc.), but also what kind of information to collect about it. In many settings, agents face problems that are informationally demanding: the payoff-relevant object is multi-dimensional (even infinite-dimensional), the information sources available to learn about the object are numerous and correlated, and the resources dedicated to such learning are scarce. If the agent is to learn optimally, she must selectively focus on information sources that she deems most central to her decision problem. For example, a firm might not know its demand function across many segments of diverse consumers. Due to shared characteristics across consumers, demand might be correlated in intricate ways across segments and the firm engages in trial-and-error learning about a few select segments. The overarching contribution of this award is to generalize the framework of Jovanovic and Rob (1990) and Callander (2011) to a large class of Gaussian processes. 

Three lines of work were advanced within the context of the award. First, the paper “Attributes: Selective Learning and Influence” (forthcoming in Econometrica) introduces this Gaussian process framework in the context of the optimal attribute learning problem. This paper developed tools on Markov and non-Markov Gaussian processes that promise to be useful in future work that uses this framework in other learning environments. Second, “Local Evidence and Diversity in Minipublics” (co-authored with Nina Bobkova and published in the Journal of Political Economy) uses a particular Gaussian process, the Ornstein-Uhlenbeck process, to model correlation in the evidence that can be produced by different players in order to address a new set of questions in political economy. Besides the methodological contribution, this paper is the first to formalize a novel form of citizen participation in the evaluation of public policies, known as minipublics. Third, ongoing work "Causal Experimentation" (that was started towards the end of the award period) studies a model of dynamic experimentation over a causal graph of Gaussian variables to understand how a long-lived decision maker might benefit from mechanism experiments—i.e., experiments that generate information about causal links that mediate the effect from the policy to the outcome—rather than policy experiments, which test the aggregate effect of the policy on the outcome.
